number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I'll be straightforward.I don't have a problem with the ubi launcher. It's a fail, but it does the job done. When it works.I don't have a problem with the dumped down resources. Although i prefer the old system, i can live with it.I don't have a problem with difficulty in general. Sometimes it can get rediculous, but you can also change it to easy.Where i do have the problem though, is with the games core mechanic that increases enemies army size every week like the players. It may look nice on paper and you can dump it down a little through difficult settings, but if you take your time (like me) wandering around the beautiful crafted map, or sometimes just killing every army you encounter, you'll hit sooner or later an overpowered enemy wall that you cannot cross.This is by the far the worse thing in the game in my opinion. It forces you to play fast and precise, otherwise you may end up in a really tight situation. Why? Why in earth can't i define my own game pace? It makes no sense. And if they liked that mechanism so much, why don't they just put a slider or something so the players can adjust in a precise way the amount of reinforcements enemies can get? Bad design choice.Apart of this, the game is nice with all it's problems. And it has lots, just read the following reviews. But it's also fun, has gorgeous graphics and a beautiful designed enviroment. Oh and the animations, are one of the best i've seen, kudos to the animation team/studio.It's a good game, full of bad design choices. A  5/10  from a series veteran.A solid  7/10  for the newcomers or the ones who simply don't care.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												I love the M&M series and have been playing it since HOMM 2 (I later went and purchased the bundle pack of HOMM 2 so I could experience HOMM 1). This game brings alot of changes to the series and I personally like the fresh take on the series. Major changes include, the new leveling system, spell system, blood and tears system, and dynasty system.The leveling system is different in this entry in that you actually get to choose the path and perks of your hero as they level. While this gets rid of a bit of the luck side of things when leveling it adds a strategy layer to picking your perks and leveling your hero. For those new to the series, in older games when your hero leveled you got to pick from a selection of randomly generated perks and skills. Sometimes you got the ones you wanted... sometimes you didnt. I can see how some loyal heroes fans would be upset about this major change but I personally enjoyed it. I felt like I had far more control over the outcome of my hero.The spell system in this entry has been overhauled as well. In previous games you would have schools of magic and spells that fell under those schools. You'd build mage guilds in your towns and get a random selection of spells from different schools of magic. Certain Factions were more likely to get specific magic types. In this game schools of magic are only available to certain factions. Spells and perks that you would get from a school of magic are part of the leveling system. When you level up you can pick a spell, a skill, or a perk. You no longer learn spells from mage guilds and shrines. I can understand how this draws away from classic heroes and can upset some devout fans but I believe the outcome is better. You can learn your spells on the fly (without having to go back to town everytime you buy a new level in the mage guild), Certain high level spells are restricted to level requirements (no level 5 guy smashing your team with death ripple), and you can pick between a weaker but wider range of spells or focus in a specific school and make those spells stronger. Again I believe it adds an extra layer of strategy and gets rid of some of the luck.the Blood and Tears System is an entirely new addition to the heroes franchise. The system rewards consistant gameplay style by giving you points towards your style. Blood being ruthless and tears being compasionate. You gain points for actions such as persuing and slaughtering lesser creatures (blood), or allowing them to flee (tears). When you get enough points your hero gains a special perk garnered to that gameplay style. It's an interesting feature and certainly brings something to the table. I found myself many a time slaughtering weak armies just for the blood points when i'd normally let them flee just to save combat time.The Dynasty system is a new addition as well. This particular addition came with some powerful perks at the cost of a miriad of major drawbacks. Perks include weapons with their own leveling system that can be passed from hero to hero and small perks that could give a starting advantage to new games. The DRM system forces you to be online in order to take advantage of the perks you can gain through dynasty. It can be relatively annoying if your playing games and you are disconnected. All in all I enjoyed the game and got my moneys worth out of it. While I understand that the vast majority of the negative reviews are for bugs or the DRM system the game itself is worth playing and is IMO the best HOMM available on steam. That being said HOMM 3 (and its expansions) is probably still my favorite entry in the series and is available on GOG.

												New to the Series? This game is a good starting point! Worried about the User Review? The game had a horrible launch with connection issues, bugs and so on... but it was years ago.Story and Lore ? I liked it, the graphics + music + voice acting + decent story, can be pretty immersive. Gameplay? Pretty standard, if you a heroes vet you might not like it. Because some simplifying of features has been done, but on the other hand they added some other things, like a progress system, for your account and for special weapons.Why to bother with a review this late? Because overall i enjoyed this game and it makes me sad seeing  49% review rate... its like a heavy scar that the game will always carry on for the mistakes of the past, if i would guess i think this game would have sit on 80% rate at least if it was released at its current state.Something to be aware of although : Dont buy this for the multiplayer, its pretty much dead.And it seems that some people are still experiencing problems, i had zero of those and i think that 99% of the problems can be fixed, just need to understand how, but its definitely something to consider before getting the game. If you never had issues with Ubisoft or fixed any you had then i dont think you will have any with this game either.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I have spend many hours in the campaign, which is quite good.  However, due to how the AI seems to be given units rather than produce them like you, it feels like like King's Quest.  It's an entertaining adventure, but it does force you to play the heal/ressurect game, otherwise you will not be able to survive many hard battles.  Treat the campaign as an RPG adventure, where your stacks and hero develop with you.  Because the rest of the game is very lackluster.  The skirmishes were extremely boring, especially because you can convert cities to your faction and then recruit from a single pool.  It makes the game very snowbally, where you just throw all your stuff into one spot, and if you win, you gain another city and more of the same units.  You have to use U-play which caused problems for some, though not me.To summerize - Campaign is good, rest is bland.

												The best Heroes yet!  I think the designers have finally removed most if not all the issues with the Heroes of Might and Magic series.  (I have been playing since 1 back in the day).  I have enjoyed this one the most so far.  Let me list the issues with the last games and how they have been fixed in 6...1) Crossing your fingers whenever you hero goes up a level, hoping you get the skill you are looking for.  In 6 you may select any skill that you want.  Of course some of them require other lower level skills  and some have hero level limits.2) I have 3 town and they are so far apart, it is going to take me a week just to combine my armies.  In 6 the number of creatures you can buy per week is shared with all towns so as long as your town can build a certain unit you can recruit all of them.  (Works with special building that give you bonus units as well).3) Gosh the enemy took all my mines again and if I retake them I cannot get back to defend my town. (Not enough movement).  In 6, you can take a mine for the turn if you leave your hero on it, but as soon as you leave control returns to the player who has the closest town.  4) Issue I have with 5 - Gee that phoenix has taken 3 moved before my Earth Elemental ever got a 1.  How unfair.  I lose no questions. (Unless I am the phoenix, in this case I hope you enjoy cheese).  In 6 they do have the initiative bar but each unit only gets 1 move a turn.  Much better, so yeah all my units might take an action before yours but only 1 action.5) Wow that is the 3rd chain lightning in a row, magic is so much stronger than might...  In 6 each spell has a cool down time, so no more chain lightning each turn until my 3000 units are toast. Most spells are every 3 turns.6) Alright I am going to build a magic tower, cross fingers...  Oh crap I already have all those spells...  In 6 spells are hero abilities so you can pick whatever you want, no randomness.7) (Not a issues but a cool new thing in 6) - Units have a might and magic attack and defense.  Not just 1 value for attack and 1 for defense.  So you can have the magic user who gets destroyed by the sword but spells / magic attacks do very little to him.My only complaint so far has been the difficult, not that it is too hard but it is out of balance.  90% of the fights I can just hit auto combat and go have a cup of tea.  But the "boss" battle at the end of the map usually requires my hitting next turn for a  few weeks to get enough units to win. (This is after I exploed the whole map.  Perhaps it is my style of play.  I am an explorer not a rusher).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Plays just like it's forerunners but everything's been given a makeover. A graphical overhaul for one. The magic's been given a lot of attention and is all the better for it and it's got the usual depth for a Might and Magic Heroes game. I've played some of it's recent competitors like the King's Bounty games, Eaodor, the latest Disciples games, etc, but I have to say this played the best and was the best looking of the lot too.Downsides; extra DRM. Not content with just using Steam, you also have to create an account and password for Uplay which Ubisoft's now using with ALL their games now. So you've got one lot of DRM on top of another DRM! Talk about giving the legitimate buyers a hard time! The pirates won't have to put up with all this everytime they want to play the game.If you can overlook that, I would say Might and Magic: Heroes VI is the best of the genre at the moment.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												It's great that they finally came out with another Heroes game after 3. It surprises me that they took so long to come out with 6. (4 and 5 don't exist. Sorry.) Overall, I think it's a big step up. Except for one fatal flaw: The game crashes constantly. I like the unique and diverse creatures and abilities, modified talent/spell trees, and focusing the game more on the combat and exploration. Overall, while they're not next-gen, the graphics are pretty good. The AI's are improved, but still somewhat predictable. On the merits of the game itself, I'd rate it a solid 8/10. But then comes all the user experience things that Ubisoft managed to screw up. Like, forcing you to create an Ubisoft account, and use Ubisoft's (terrible) launcher and cloud system for your saved games. Assuming it doesn't break partway through, it's really slow on the upload. Oh, and did I mention the game breaks more often than a union employee? Finish a computer-initiated battle? Well, let's lock up. Trying to enter one of your domains? I'm sorry, Dave. And these crashes are common and unpredictable, with no common factors, which is the biggest problem. The game becomes almost unplayable, because Ubisoft can't be bothered to debug its code properly. You might get a 2 hour stretch. You might get 2 minutes. Roll the dice. Taking the crashes into account, I give it a solid 5/10. When it works, it works; it's just dealing with all the time it doesn't.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Half decent game, although much of the stuff gets messed up by ubisoft. The fact that they introduced a "in game free currency" is kind of silly, because you actually need it for some good dynastical perks that can change your game alot. Also there is quite the imbalance when it comes to campaign heroes, whereas mage heroes can take off a whole army while might heroes can only do warcries that aren't even that good. Heroes of Might and Magic V actually had a better balance compared to this game, but in this game some factions are insanely overpowered, granting them the power to revive their best units with just gold, and with that when a person has map control they can continuosly attack your town without giving that much of a care. Netplay in the game works, but its the same as playing a full game of Civ, in which it will take a extremely long time and it will be excrutiatingly painful. The conflux orb idea was indecent because you could only type up so little for a guide, and even if you wanted a guide it would be better to make some kind of strat. guide instead of just placing them all around the various maps. To continue, the pacing in the story maps was really quick, and much of it didn't make sense. X or Y died every so often and there isn't much you can do about it. Many weird and funky plot twists were included to make sure "you were getting your fill of cool gamer storyline grub". To conclude this, the campaign mode was too short and extremely buggy, netplay is really slow, textures are extremely lowres and unnapealing.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Might & Magic Heroes VI is a turn-based strategy video game for Microsoft Windows developed by Black Hole Entertainment and published by Ubisoft. It is the sixth installment in the Heroes of Might and Magic series, and was released on October 13, 2011, coinciding with the 25th anniversary of the Might and Magic franchise. Heroes VI acts as a prequel to Heroes of Might and Magic V, occurring almost five centuries earlier, and is set in the fictional world of Ashan. The story follows the five heirs to the Griffin dynasty in their quests to repel a demon invasion and assist or impede Michael, a legendary Archangel general plotting to revive an ancient war.As in previous Heroes of Might and Magic titles, the player can choose between single-player or multiplayer modes of play, and controls a number of heroes and towns associated with various factions, commanding armies of creatures between tactical overland exploration and a turn-based combat system to satisfy each scenario's victory conditions. Heroes VI alters some of the series' long-standing conventions, overhauling its chance-based skills system and reducing the number of resources in its economics model, and also introduces new mechanics, including a points-based reputation system and the ability to convert one faction's towns to another.Heroes VI has been received positively, attaining a score of 77 from the aggregate review site Metacritic. Reviewers praised the title's replay value, visuals and improvements to the Heroes formula, but were critical of the numerous bugs and glitches in the release version and its intrusive DRM system, which requires players to maintain a connection to the Internet to avail of several features.

												A lot of the negative reviewes here WERE probably true, but a lot of patches have gone by since the original release of the game. I was a minor fan of HOMM III, but I found it too difficult and confusing, but the tutorial for this game covers just about everything. There was not a single aspect of this game I found unclear, and the graphics is realy nice(although characters tend to be on the ugly side). If you're a fan of the series defintely check this game out, it's pretty much a better version of HOMM III in my opinion.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This is probably the best Heroes of Might and Magic game. While Heroes II had better campaigns in it, the Heroes VI campaigns remain good. The AI is excellent - a serious challenge to beat in some battles. Heroes VI also removes one of the most tedious things about HOMM (and i say that as someone who loves these games), which is having to do a running tour of all your cities to keep your armies equalling or outnumbering the AI's.In Heroes VI you can recruit troops with a hero in any town, from any town, speeding things up massively.The option to build advanced town portals that let you teleport between towns you control speed things up again. And since the AI can build the same portals it doesn't make the game any easier.Heroes of different factions also get completely different skill trees from one another, which adds to the variety of the game a lot.The graphics are nice, so is the music. The one downside to Heroes VI compared to earlier games in the series is that to get the best starting bonuses you can get you have to play it online via uplay, which, when you're playing single player, is just a bit of a pain that slows starting a new game or loading a saved one down a bit.This is a minor annoyance though in what is basically a really great game.Some HOMM fans deride Heroes VI for having made some changes to previous games. The mess of Heroes VII resulting from trying to go backwards instead of forwards shows how mistaken those people are imo.The one thing that Heroes VI hasn't changed is that it's still in big part a matter of who can recruit more troops faster - but that's a flaw in the basic type of game it is, not this version of it.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												Heroes 6 can be described as massive. It could also be described as tedious and arbitary. The size of this game is colossal. There is so much to do and to customise, it is hard to know where to start. The turnside of this is that it is hard to come to grips with, and slow. The game offers you deep strategic gameplay and character building, but progress is slow and enemies grow too powerful too fast. Which leads to tedious grinding and almost boring gameplay which was exicting a turn earlier. But none of this troubles you when you are immersed in this grand and excellent experience of top notch rpg tactic. And that is the problem, you cannot get immersed because of Ubisofts ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRM. You'll spend more time trying to get the save files synched than actually playing. Actually getting the game to work merits an achievement cause you need to verify so many codes and agreements it's almost unheard of. Honestly, the game itself is terrific, but the included shackles are very stifling.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Ok..so this is the first time I actually decided to give my opinion on a purchase. Frankly i'm kinda amazed at all the negative comments. But to be fair I just have not encountered ANY of the issues others are complaining about. Keep in mind Ive only played it for about 3 hours. YES... the game does need UPlay to run. If this an issue for you do not buy it. To me it is no big deal. However they SHOULD put that in the Description so people that this is an issue for KNOW it before the purchase.THat being said...I haven't played the Might and Magic series since it was on 3.5 disks. I just remember that i really enjoyed playing the game so I decided to try this one. I only paid 7.50 for it so i figured no biggie if i didn't like it. But so far i LOVE IT. The installation went flawlessly...and since i already had a U-Play account that part of it was also seamless and i had ZERO issues launching the game after installation. When it asks for the CD Key you need to put in the KEY for the Main game ONLY. The DLC codes are updated automatically I assume since I never had to put them in but they are available from the beginning. As far as bad acting goes...(voicovers) umm really ??? that matters to people ??? Oh well I guess i am just to interested in Gameplay ...not so much on dialog...especially in a game like this. Now if it was a survival horror or fantasy first person rpg where story is super important for atmosphere or moving the story along then yeah Dialog and acting is important but for this particular game ehh!!!Graphics are great and gameplay is simple even if you have NEVER played a Might and Magic game before. I am running an old duo core amd 3.2 CPU with 8 GB ram and a Radeaon 4650  with 1gb ram and have zero issues so far with crashes or lock ups. THe game runs smooth and looks amazing compared to the older M&M games that I remember. As far as the other issues that some of the more experienced M&M players have talked about I just have not had any yet. Over all I think this a great game for those of us that like Turn Based as opposed to Real Time strategy games and i would recommend it (WHILE IT IS ON SALE) to anyone that is into Turn Based Fantasy Stategy games. That is my humble opinion and EVERYONE is entitled to MY opinion!!!  :) Peace

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												A must for tactical games enthusiasts with hardcore RPG elements. Deep characters, extremely detailed world and packed with heaps of lore and fantasy elements. The colors are extremely vivid and just outright gorgeous, probably the prettiest colors I've seen in a PC game so far. The soundtrack was beautifully crafted, being very pleasant to the ear and fitting to the game's atmosphere at all times. Online play is quite satisfactory and will keep you interested along with the game's already massive natural appeal in it's own right. If you liked games like Warcraft 3 and enjoys turn-based strategy you can't go wrong with this game, it's one of the finest blends of such genres so far, you'll find it's gameplay quite unique.I suggest buying the complete version, as it is much, much cheaper than buying the standalone expansions afterwards. You won't regret it!

												I'm a fan of Heroes of Might and Magic, and as much as I wanted to enjoy this game, I didn't. Firstly the difficulty is insane even on easy, due to inbalanced A.I. It's the classic example of having bad A.I. programming, only to try to make it up by making it hugely owerpowered, meaning that you will be attacked by enemies with way too many troops for you to handle.The issues with Uplay are there as well, maning long load times if you're connected to the internet, and lost feautures if you're not. To make it worse saves made with Uplay turned off aren't compatable when playing online, and vice versa. Stick to the older HoMM titles, don't waste your time with this.

 One of the best Turn base strategy games in a world. Game play. Heroes 6 keeps in Heroes 3 traditions gameplay, but stil with changes that makes game even better. Interface is now more comfortable than ever before.  Resources now have only gold, wood, ore and crystals as special resource for advanced buildings and creatures. Of course its matter of taste, but still with this graphic game perform quite terribly. Game seams lack of optimization. With my hardware this game should fly. Game still playable but suffers some serious frame drops. And Heroes profile leveling gives a game adicional value. They call it a Dynasty.ConclusionGame is good, but there need some work to done in order get some genius turn based game which was Heroes 3 at the time. Strategy fans don't need fancy graphic. If you still happy about game after long sessions this means game is good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												I would recommend this game overall but this is not one of the best games out there. This game exhibits great RPG elements, and mastering an expertise in battle requires dynamic strategies. However, there are many issues that I have with the game as well. For example the AI is stupid; there are two settings: aggressive and defensive. If you play against defensive then the AI only stockpiles units, which means you will eventually win by sheer force from taking over the map. If you play against aggressive then enemy heroes will only engage in battles that they win in, but only return back to base if forced to. This means that (1) you won't enter in any battles unless your slated to lose (which sometimes means that no matter how resourceful and strategic you are, you will lose); and (2) if you reinforce your main hero then you will eventually overpower the enemy. However, this tends to just end up the AI playing chicken to take your city and you just sitting there until you abuse bad AI scripting to, for example, make them miscalculate. While this makes players think, this doe not make for interesting or fun gameplay. The campaign offers relief from this type of AI stupidity but only sometimes; however, the campaigns did contain some maps that were definitely a puzzle. To be honest, the only reason I recommend this game is because the combat system is engaging, and by abusing the computer's stupidity of amassing units; can reach battles of epic proportions. The hero powers become essential in achieving victory and is the best way this game hands control into the player's hands: all units are balanced among the different races, but it really is how you build your hero that defines a win from a loss. If I could make an ideal 4x game, Heroes of Might & Magic IV would be the type of combat that my game would emulate. That's how fun and different it is from say CIV or SC. However, there are many better strategy games that offer more meaningful experiences where the player has much more choice, not just in hero customization but in building a kingdom. I bought this game thinking it was a strategy game: let me be clear; if that's why you would buy it then do not. This game is an RPG game with strategy elements. Find loot, defend your bases and points of interest; and win by sheer force. If you want a game where you get to control massive and visually epic battles then I'd recommend this game for you.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I first played MM in the 90s and had fond memories. I picked up MM6 as part of the sell here on Steam intendeing a few hours of fun over the holidays. I was disappointed.I think the basic problem with this game is that it doesn't know what it wants to be when it grows up. It has some character development but not enough to hold one's interest. It has city development but the options are straight forward and uninteresting. Most of my time was spent fighting battles and this is the most disappointing part of the game.The battles are highly artificial and repetitive. The battle board is always the same size with perhaps a few rocks or tree stumps thrown about. There is no ZOC so the enemy just walks around your army. Many tactics therefore make use the edges or corners, giving it the feel of a chess game . You can only deploy 7 units. The size of the units is not constrained, so I had my 1200 archers next to my 33 spearmen. I just couldn't get the feeling of fighting a real fantasy battle. Worst of all, it just felt like the same thing again and again.BTW, if you don't have a stable full time internet connection you will not want this game. Unless you are online you are not allowed to have many in game perks. If you lose the your connection in the middle of the game it just dumps you out and you can't get back in until the connection is up again. An off line mode is offered, but once you go online again, there is no way to go back to off line.I still think there is a market niche for a game like this if it achieves a better blend of character, city and army development. MM6 is close but just doesn't get there.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												I mean... It's HoMM.  Features some interesting improvements over previous incarnations in the series, such as Dynasty Weapons and benefits of controlled territory around cities, and the skilling system is interesting.Suffers a bit from poor optimization, like many other Ubisoft titles, and has a tendency to run sluggishy or choppily, regardless of graphics settings.Is also victim to the recent cancerous gaming growth of "required online connectivity to play," even when playing the single player campaign.  If at any time while playing, you lose connection to the internet (or more importantly, if Uplay goes down, which it frequently does,) your game will immediately exit without saving and you'll be punted back to the main menu.  It's a pretty heartbreaking way to lose a ton of progress.Still, if you're aching for a HoMM game, this is one.  So, that's probably enough for some folks.  Suppose it's recommended, though only by virtue of being a sequel in a series that was once near and dear to my heart.

												They broke all good old mechanics. If V were like "let's take best from III and IV and add some nice graphics", VI is "Let's make it easier and reduce strategy to battlefield only". Difficult choice between two skills on lvl-up? No, you can take any. Making all armies from different cities unite before final battle? No, you can Hire all armies at once in nearest castle. Trying to protect your elven-city while your whole army is undead? No more, any city is converted to your type...So what will be VII? Press (X) to win?Let's say something good... Soundtrack is OK, graphics are less fairy than in V (though a bit rough for me), new story-line with weird-named necromancer (Sveltana), achievement system, leveling dynasty weapons (or is it actually bad thing? Why should weapon level-up, it doesn't make any sense).Launching game is rather weird. Firs time I pressed Play in steam, it installed and ran UPlay, then asked to put in the key, so that I could press play button in UPlay... And every time I press Play in steam... It opens UPlay, so that I could press Play there. Awkward and confusing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												First and foremost, HOMM6 is steeped in DRM. If this isn't your thing, be warned. You have to use Ubisoft's highly lame login system which causes me overlay issues with Steam and is generally mildly and endlessly annoying. On the flip side, you earn Uplay points when playing the game which can be used to unlock Ubisoft rewards to the game, such as wallpapers, extra PC cards for avatars, and even a Hero PC.The game has been a better experience in the past. Chiefly, the campaign story feels very rollercoaster; that is to say, you can't get off the rails. Each event leads to the next event, which in turns leads to the next one. In previous incarnations, the game almost encouraged exploration. I felt like I was exploring only what it wanted me to find up until the chokepoints. This made the game feel taxing.Graphically, it looks good. A bit like The Frozen Throne though; cartoony, bright. Combat is very close to what one would remember from previous versions. For those who haven't played this series, combat is tactical. Once you engage an enemy on the larger map, a somewhat randomized battle map appears before you. On one side is your hero and your army. On the other, the enemies (possibly an enemy hero). Combat turns fall to whichever units are faster than others, thus making a hastened group a good group. Attack power, defense, and special abilities fall into the mix as well. As does your hero's abilities. The magical gear in the game is pretty cool overall, with a lot of variety to the pieces and plenty of set gear that offers bonuses when you combine them with other pieces of the set. Also a nice addition are the legacy weapons.Where I found the game to be weak is in the enemy AI. It was far too predictable and at some points, just makes really bad decisions. So bad and so common, that I could predict exactly how the computer was going to attack. This detracts from the game. HOMM6 isn't a bad game, but it has been more exciting in the past. Whenever this game is $20 or less, it is a good purchase.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												It's, at first, somewhat difficult to get into if you are used to the other Heroes games. It's not your standard Heroes game, with random skills, yet I would not say it's a bad change. It got a pretty art style, and I would dare say it's rather satifying to build your own hero.  The sadest part of the whole game, is that there will most likely not be any more DLC, as Blackhole was sacrificed to release the vanilla of the game, leaving it without the Wizards and hippy elfs. My major complaint about the game, is the online and offline system. Being two different saves, playing offline and online can be very annoying. Suddenly you find yourself without internet, eager to continue the amusing (Yet somewhat.. Unfinished) story of Sandro, and you can't. Why? Because it's not saved offline. That would be online, on Ubisoft's own servers. And of course, if they are having problems with their severs, that will indeed mean exactly that, you cannot continue your save. This is very annoying to say the slightest. You get rewarded for playing online, with weapons, achivs and a dynasty to level up, yet Heroes is the kind of game I've always felt was made for a offline hot-set experience, NOT an online only experience.  Combined with unstable servers... Just no .So, being somewhat punchished for playing offline is just silly, and I cannot see the problem with just having one save, and no limits on the online servers. To sum up, I liked the game, having a brilliant art style, a fun ability system, and some good stories. Yet, I cannot help to feel the save system ruin it. It's just a bad system, though the dynasty and weapon level is a fun addition, it could just as well have been offline. Knowing there wont be any more, as Blackhole was sacrificed by Ubisoft to create the Vanilla, is sad, but yet, I would recommand at least trying it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I've always been a fan of the Heroes of Might and Magic franchise. I am not, however, for Heroes VI. The game has improved graphics, UI, and voice acting over its predecessor Heroes V, but several mechanical changes in resources and faction combinations restrict from enjoying the newest game of the franchise.Resources are reduced down to just: wood, ore, crystal, and gold. Mercuary, gems and sulfur are excluded that were once present in the older games of the series. Reduction of resources makes building less of a hassle, though too simplistic. Factions having their own affinity to a resource gave them a unique quality. It helped drive strategy for the hero and faction you were playing for, you strived to control them over the others as they were important to you. Just having crystal doesn't lend to exploration or additional map control that was a key factor of the gameplay of the Heroes of Might and Magic games.But that's not the biggest gripe to have over this game. What erks me is the shared creature population pool in the campaign missions that don't allow you to build a large enough army to beat the tutorial level within a short amount of time (I was literally at month 5 still waiting on creature populations to build up to attack the last fort before I simply decided to quit). This literally makes the campaign harder and longer than necessary to mask the underlying flaws.While Heroes V had some crippling bugs that hampered its launch in 2006, they eventually were patched and resolved, even modded. Ubisoft no longer supports Heroes VI and the last patch was 2.1.1 from October 2012. There are still game breaking bugs for quests not working corectly in the campaign that require a reload from a previous save file or a complete restart of the campaigns themselves.The custom maps and scenarios were the only escape from the mired campaign. The game ships with a decent number of non-campaign maps and an editor to create your own. Map quality and scenarios increase as more expansions are acquired. Boy, the editor brings back some memories of building your masterpiece(s) extra-large or huge maps that took weeks to complete and then finally playing them. However, the custom maps, scenarios and map editor can't redeem this game.With the reduction of resources and low creature populations, the game also limits to five different factions - Necromancer, Dungeon, Haven, Inferno, and Sanctuary. The previous games had a more bevy and robust roster of factions to choose from. Out of nine total factions, we are left with just these five. Four factions are familiar to the Heroes series: Dungeon, Haven, Inferno and Necromancer. The other two seem like a mash up of factions that appeared earlier in ther series. Rampart from Heroes III  and Heroes IV is combined with the Wizard (a.k.a Tower) from Heroes II and III to form the oriental themed Sanctuary. On the other hand, Stronghold makes a second appearance that is a throw back to the Barbarian (Heroes I to IV) and Fortress (Heroes III and IV) factions. The experiance is similar to  seeing an old friend after a long time, but dissapointed after finding out nothing really interesting happened has happened except maybe a change in thematic style (Santuary) or haven't improved much over time (Haven).The game has the sence that a lot of  attention was directed into the UI, art, and graphical aspects rather than gameplay. It's a nice game to look at, but not fun to play due to numerous bugs and sacrifices in mechanics. There was even an open beta in August of 2011 before the launch that Steam members could participate in. After reviewing those members experiance, it seems Ubisoft rushed the game and didn't heed players feedback.I have to give this a "no" recommendation for the very fact that it just isn't very fun to play, at all. I'd rather load up Heroes V even with all its faults, which were ironed out through two expansions. Sometimes I crave earlier iterations such as Heroes III that is still heavily supported by fans across the internet to this day. Did you know there were tournaments held on a website for Heroes III alone? After almost 15 years, that game is still played, not like Heroes VI.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												If you are tempted to fall into the trap of condemning Heroes VI based on either Ubisoft's distribution platform, or based on a love of the earlier installments in the series, don't be. Ubisoft's system is preferable to some other alternatives I will refrain from naming.I feel far too many of the negative reviews on the game are based on the short period of downtime the network experienced during release. Given that for all intents and purposes, Uplay now works without issue, I'd like to say those concerns are invalid.It's still heroes of might and magic. The gameplay is faster paced, the design is tighter, and the game is orders of magnitude more sleek and pretty than it's predecessor, which felt old even the day it was released. The essentials of the game remain quite similar, and I have few complaints with these choices.Expect a few significant changes to mechanics (by and large positive) and a slightly annoying 'Dynasty System' that facilitates Uplay's online achievements. (Easy to ignore and can be disabled when creating a game for balance reasons, presumably.)Having played all of the games in the series, I am extremely grateful that this IP got picked up and given another modern spin. Given the underwhelming lack of support for this game, I'm sad to say it might be the last.

												The game is good. It is not a HoM&M game in the traditional fashion, and therefore I think it's a good thing they changed the name to M&M:H. The problem with the game itself is that Ubisoft art ♥♥♥♥tards who cannot finish a game properly. The main game is not very buggy anymore, but the DLC "Danse Macabre" is  still terribly bugged. It freezes in the same fights over and over, and sometimes the map does not even load properly, making it seem like you basically turned gamma off. Apart from that, the campaigns are interesting, the factions are fairly diverse (IMO), and the new concept with more RPG in terms of hero leveling and such is spot on per my preferences. The biggest con of this game is the fact that you absolutely HAVE to be online to enjoy it's full potential. I love the dynasty part of it, it makes me want to accomplish stuff in the same way steam achievements do, but is it really necessary with an online connection for it? It's a singleplayer game you dimwits.Now to the elephant in the room. WARNING: there will be a lot of hearts censoring the full extent of my fury.uPlay. The useless ♥♥♥♥ing piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥it is is what ruins this game for most people. 1st rule of uPlay: Turn off in-game overlay. It is bugged as ♥♥♥♥ and will mess up your game. Secondly; Ubisoft are some beta ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥who thinks that if they do not force their games through their own useless crap copy of steam we will not know it is their game and they will not earn money or some stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥like that. 												As a returning player to this game...the only thing I can say is: This game should be avoided at all costs. At least in its current state, which i doubt will change soon, since Ubisoft are more focused on the next one in the series. One of the proofs is that they still havent fixed the locked cursor bug, where u cannot use it to navigate to the sides on the map - a bug which i remember from the first month after it came out. So that says all about their customer support and their involvement post-production.The game by itself is good, decent story, good graphics, a lil' more dynamic than the other Heroes in my view...alas that could only be useful as an info, if u can play it. Uplay is making it impossible to play. It crashes constantly. Some people tend to get around the problem. It doesnt work for me however. I tried it all, downloading uplay directly from the site, deleting the profile folder, reinstalling, running as administrator...none of them worked. Some people claim that returning their drivers to a 2012 version per say fixed it for them. But for me that option sounds ridiculous - to change GPU drivers for one game with a terrible client. It should be the other way around, not us adapting to suit the weaknesses of a product we purchased...a product that is supposed to be patched correctly.All in all, stay away from any Uplay products...you might be opening the Pandora's box purchasing them. They only exist to help Ubisoft feed off of franchises created by others.

												Definitely recommend!I had almost zero problems getting into the game and when there was an issue, I just started the game file as an adminstrator (look on the game forum for help).  Any time Ubisoft updated their software, I'd have to do it.  No big deal really.I bought this game on sale with all of the DLC.  GREAT VALUE!!  With that being said, I've played HOMM 2-6 and this series did not dissapoint at all.  I very much enjoyed the smooth game play and great storyline.  I'm on my entire 2nd playthrough, this one on hard (trying to get some of those dynasty weapons to lvl 5).  I also like the Dynasty system et al.  It added another layer that was previously not there.  I like it alot.  My ONLY issue  is the order in which you play the main campaign.  It's shown from left to right with the Tutorial missions first and then the Necro followed by Haven, Sacntuary, Inferno, and Stronghold.   I believe the best way to play the main campaign is chronologically versus each faction.    I suppose that's a matter of opinion though.  Either way, it was still a blast to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												I usually don't write reviews. I usually don't feel very strongly about the games I play. They are games, I enjoy them to a certain degree, but that is about the extent of my emotional investment. Now that we have this personal tidbit out of the way, let me begin by saying that I honestly like the Heroes franchise, which includes even the current atrocity and the (for many fans, anyway) mediocre installment that went before it.That is, I would really like to enjoy this game, but for the life of me I can't. Not that it doesn't have some strong suits: The unit models are downright gorgeous, and watching them duke it out in a Heroes-style arena is quite enjoyable. I don't even mind the weak storyline, the presentation of which makes you want to pop some ecstacy (figuratively speaking, of course) just to stay awake. I don't even mind, and I honestly didn't expect much to begin with.What I do mind is the absolutely distasteful, punch-in-the-face, DRM-nightmare platform that Ubisoft ever so tactfully forces upon the player, who put down hard cash to begin with and is most likely eager to play. But wait (and, trust me, you will have to wait a lot if you play this game, but more on that later), first create an account with the fun-loving, family-good-time platform that is Uplay. Already, that dreadful feeling of regret is kreeping along my spine as I feast my eyes, for the very first time, on Uplay and what will from now on be my personal window into the game. I blink once, I blink twice, I try my hardest to ignore the plethora of pile upon pile of achievement, cosmetic-personalization, and fictional-monies/credit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I look only for two things: Activate offline mode and play.The game loads, finally, the main menu appears. Naturally, the game is played. Strangely, some options in the character window are greyed out. The cold sweats are creeping back in. Immediately, I shut down and look for articles that explain this so-called in-game dynasty (not that it requires rocket science).Within minutes, it becomes painfully obvious that, should you choose or want to play the game offline, you're basically looking at a crippled product. Only if you connect to your account are you allowed to choose boni, with which your alter ego begins their adventure, dynasty weapons, pets, and custom heroes (otherwise, the one provided has to do). And, while it is true that these are mere boni, which add to, but are not strictly required in order to finish the game, you're always reminded how you may miss out whenever you find a new dynasty weapon or similar. (It is here I believe Ubisoft's lack of publishing talent is wasted on the gaming industry. They might want to consider psychological warfare.) Best of all, however,  if you wish to reset your progress, you're♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck: What you do online, stays, at least until Ubisoft goes out of business. Above, I mentioned that your patience will be tested by this game, and it is true. Virtually every minute, you will be greeted by a loading screen. You start the game -- loading screen, you load a save -- loading screen (so far, so normal). The loading screen will stare at you for what will soon become an eternity. You are prompted to press any key to continue. You are now in the game world, but, lo and behold, certain items are missing -- such as your character, or other characters, or flags, or anything animated, really, because these are loaded on the fly after the loading screen (sick of the word "load", yet?) You enter your town, haven, or whatever you want to call it, and the screen says "Loading ..." for a bit. You enter battle, and the screen goes black (loading the battle scene, I presume), and sometimes the scene doesn't load at all. This happens before about 5 % to 10 % of all battles, thusly crashing the game. I cannot quite remember if Uplay attempts to synchronize your saves (a "feature", which can be turned off, fortunately), but when it does, know that you will stare at your screen for 2 to 5 minutes during synchronization.All this being said, I almost pity the developer for having to work under the yoke of Ubisoft and did not (it seems to me) have the opportunity to realize the full potential of the game -- even after the many patches.At any rate, Heroes VI will definitely be the last game I bought that has the Ubisoft sticker on it.
